Comment: This is a ridiculous debate to even have.  The single largest hurdle wind/solar cannot pass over is "energy density;" ie, it simply requires too much 'space' to produce; on millions of acres of a limited resource: Land.  

Wind/solar would have to expand 10 times its current land use to come close to replacing carbon-based generation.  That doesn't account for future capacity needs beyond 2040.  Even the sea-based projects have significant return problems for the money spent.  Polis and Johnston are typical opportunists, preying on an engineering-deficient and largely uninformed electorate.  

If we stay on the 'renewables' path, the economics kill solar/wind long before we hit 2030.  2040 is a 'pipedream.'

Comment: Thank you Officer Nave for doing this and helping make Anchorage a better place for all.  We all play a part in making Anchorage a safe place to live. For the people that only care about money, it takes an investment in the quality of life issues to reap the later reward of cost savings.  Fewer calls for service means officer's have more time for proactive patrols. Less crime means less arrests. The "broken windows" theory has some truth to it, but it's more than just property upkeep. It's also taking smaller crimes, including quality of life issues seriously. I've seen COPS (Community Oriented Policing) programs take back neighborhoods. But only when the neighborhood buys into the program too. Traffic enforcement is part of it, but not just during "peak" times. Criminals figure that out and work it to their advantage. It's using all the tools together to find the best solution. Thanks to APD for putting this program in place.

Comment: When a Canadian institution gives preference to its citizens over those from other countries while disregarding merit, it is doing itself a disservice. Comment: For all the comments that the articles about this crash have generated, no one has mentioned the role of the passenger in safeguarding his/her life. If one simply boards an aircraft and hopes for - or expects - a favorable outcome, you are betting on the competence and judgment of the pilot(s). On a scheduled (Part 121) airliner, that's usually, but not always (i.e., the regionals) a quite sound bet. But, as we have witnessed time and again in Alaska, your odds of arriving alive on an air taxi, though still good, are substantially diminished.

Most crashes are related to poor weather. For instance, the fatal VFR Hageland 208 flight that crashed in St. Mary's a couple of years ago launched at night into rapidly deteriorating weather. Despite the fact that it was ALREADY IFR in the Mtn. Village-St. Mary's area. I would have checked the weather, and would never have boarded that aircraft. Trusting the pilot and dispatcher killed a bunch of people. And the pilot was highly experienced.

Comment: It has virtually nothing to do with protected classes. There are two separate issues here. And both have been addressed by the courts. One is the nature of the cake and/or its decorations, and the other is the nature of the customer(s). In the first one, the baker has the leverage: no one can compel him to create a swastika cake, a naked body (or body parts) cake, a cake decorated with hate speech, or anything else with a shape, flavor, or decorations that the baker finds objectionable. All within any limits imposed by the relevant laws and codes. 
.
That is not the issue at hand. 
.
This is: when you open a business offering specific goods and/or services to the public, your ability to refuse service to someone is rightly limited by the relevant laws. Phillips violated those laws. If he refused to sell such a cake to a couple of neo-Nazis, that would have been a violation as well.

Comment: Let me guess MMackinnon, math isn’t your strong suit. Here’s a simple example for you, Alberta has a smaller population than Ontario so it pays less in total taxes (but more per person). Let’s keep the numbers simple, Alberta pays the feds $150 in taxes and receives $100 back in transfers as we are a net contributor. Ontario pays $500 in taxes given the larger population, however, it receives $550 back in transfers as a have not province and a net benefactor of equalization. So who paid more in taxes? We pay taxes to the fed and the fed sends transfers back to the provinces. If you receive more in transfers than you’ve paid in (as is the case with all have not provinces), by definition, you’ve paid less tax on a net basis than a have province. Equalization forces you to look at everything on a net basis. Net of transfer payments, Ontario does not pay the largest portion of federal taxes. It’s illogical to look at taxes in isolation from transfer payments given equalization.

Comment: The key reason Buffett was confident of winning was that he was betting the S&P 500 against a group of several fund of funds and therefore many dozens of  hedge funds. This meant he was not risking a bet against one or a few hedge funds that might beat the index. A group of funds of funds would mean he was betting against basically the average hedge fund. Math was on his side. He was betting average with low costs could beat average with high costs. There was risk because the average hedge fund was not restricted to the S&P 500. But he probably knew that the average hedge fund has a good exposure to the S&P 500 and in any case he had that huge cost advantage on his side.

 "the S&P 500 will outperform a portfolio of funds of hedge funds"

Comment: The thing to be aware of about regarding dopamine supplements in sport is that, regardless of whether a person has a medical condition, taking a dopaminergic delivers all the athletic-enhancement that constitutes doping.

There is no difference in enhancement between Canadian, USA, Norwegian, or any other athletes who use dopaminergics while claiming medical need, and any other athlete who also dopes without claiming medical need: The enhancement to performance development due to taking the dopaminergic is there all the same, and doesn't politely not factor in because the athlete is taking the dopaminergic for some particular condition (and most athletes wouldn't claim to have their conditions apart from it allowing them to dope).

So, when an Olympian who is "legally" allowed to dope by claiming a medical condition wins a medal, the medal should be noted as different than an actual full medal-award. It should be a partial-win, or a win with conditions, or something along those lines.

Comment: Winter tires have two significant flaws: they wear out very quickly, and they tend to be much noisier. The ratings (from Canadian Tire, e.g.) are not entirely (pun?) to be relied on, because they only test brand-new tires. An aggressive tread pattern will get much, much noisier after a year or two. And the wear rating depends on how you drive, your car's alignment being perfect, and the loads you carry. Realize that the cost of tires can be a significant part of car ownership.

That being said, winter tires (4 of them) are still worthwhile in terms of safety, BUT ONLY IF YOU DRIVE SANELY AND DEFENSIVELY. Observe that the owners of 4-wheel drive vehicles end up in the ditch a lot more than the rest of us; the reason for this seems to escape those drivers.

Comment: I've seen Gasland and Josh Fox (the director) has been proven to be a liar on multiple occasions. Gasland is not an accurate portrayal of what can go wrong at all and contains a ton of BS. The faucets catching fire are caused by biogenic methane from shallow coal seams and had been happening decades before fracking began. Josh Fox knew this and blatantly lied about it in his documentary. The origin of the gas can be proven by determining the type of gas coming out of the faucet. In a CSU study done in Weld County (shown to have flaming tap water in the documentary), gas in water wells has been shown to be biogenic in origin 98% of the time meaning it could not have originated in an oil and gas bearing formation (where thermogenic gas originates from). Comment: This is an excellent step toward ending the massive demonizing from 80 years of the world's largest propaganda campaign.  It's even more difficult than  author, Walker, imagines though, since he presents one of the those false assumptions as if were gospel, saying:

>>>"our energy should be spent on how to talk with our children about the danger to their brain development that pot presents." 

There has been intensive research on marijuana consumption and brain development.   One early study appeared to have shown adolescents who smoked marijuana ended up with less IQ than non-consumers.  -  This was quickly debunked when it was found they had not controlled for socio-economic conditions.  -  It turns out the lower IQs were due to poverty, not very surprising.

But the idea stuck and even though all subsequent research has failed to find any proof of long-lasting harms for teens (or anyone else), people  continue to mislead with the idea, intentionally or not.

Comment: Actually the wildfire response is well equipped, with well-trained personnel and good tactical leadership, and their response time is practically immediate. The "hotshots" can quickly control most fires before they get big. Weather is a big factor, and with hot dry weather and strong winds, you can't leave your personnel downwind of a fire that's blowing up. It is VERY dangerous work.

Perhaps you'd like to hire the private wildfire fighters? When I see someone writing "another failed government agency", I almost always think that is a meaningless knee-jerk reaction. Even FEMA does a good job when it has decent leadership. We'll see how FEMA does with the Texas hurricane disaster under its current director, Craig Fugate, who has considerable experience managing a dozen disasters as Florida's emergency management director. There are some lame federal agencies, but also some very good ones.

Comment: In Manitoba, most of the laboratory services are privately operated. When I get my check up, I can take the subscription for my tests to one of these privately owned, for profit services, or go to the public owned and operated service. The privately owned ones are more available and offer quicker service. In either case the government pays the full cost. The private clinics are very modest looking establishments - no frills. The private clinic simply sends the bill to the government. There is no "two tier" - the wealthy get the same service as the poor. I think this same model would work for all kinds of other services  - scans, surgeries or whatever. As a patient, I win because I didn't have to wait. Government wins because I am more likely to stay healthy if I access care in a timely fashion. In this case at least, competition works. The unionized clinics run by hospitals will simply not be used as much because the private service es are equal and quicker.

Comment: Busting street dealers is virtually pointless since (at least in the DTES) they're usually users themselves being paid in cash + drugs to sling gear on the corner; detain one and another takes his place the next morning.

Busting the higher-ups is more effective but costs enormous time and money--witnesses, surveillance, warrants, etc .. and even then there's no long-term effect since one guy's arrest is another guy's business opportunity. 

Arresting dealers does NOTHING to change demand. Arresting users does even less.

People have always done drugs and always will do--alcohol, coca and opium use go back thousands of years. The sooner we accept this and move toward a regulated production and distribution system of all recreational drugs--which are vastly safer when made to pharmaceutical standards--the more lives and money and woe we'll save.

Comment: Context missing from this article. During the period of Grand Apartheid (Malan, Verwoerd, Vorster), English business were very critical of the NP and funded the opposition. PW Botha promised to reform apartheid, and with that also promised more business friendly neoliberal policies. This lead to a major rapprochement with English speaking business. The influence of the cabinet was reduced, as was the Broerderbond's, while big business got a seat at the table that now mattered: the national security management system. Botha believed socio-economic reform was part of the 'total strategy' & that he needed business for that. 

If this article purports to be all that could be found on the NP, it serves more to exonerate them than damn them. These letters don't point to corruption (in a system that allowed for far more secrecy.). In US politics anonymous donations to political parties are possible to this day. In the UK they are also allowed (but can not be anonymous).

Comment: Life is full of risks and we, as individuals and as parents, assess those risks and act accordingly.  Some decisions are easy.....the risks are high and the rewards low. For others the risks are low and the rewards high.  Then, we sometimes face the tough choices when that reward/risk comparison is a lot tougher.  IMO, encouraging or discouraging, allowing or forbidding your son or daughter playing football is one of them.  I'm 75 so I don't have that dilemma.  However, our Grandson is playing football and absolutely loves the game.  Grandma and I stay "out" of the issue and go to the games to support and enjoy his participation.  However, when I see a kid take a hard helmet hit and come up shaking his head, it makes me nervous for our Grandson and all the rest of the players.  

Some choices aren't easy....are they?   Gary Crum

Comment: Although there might be a short depression in real estate prices if inflation and mortgage rates rise, as adjustments occur in the markets,  people should look back in history to see what happened the last time.  Take the Vancouver area:  in the mid 1950's mortgage rates were low,around 4%, and a typical house sold for maybe $10,000.  By 1981, inflation in Canada was getting out of control, peaking at roughly 13%, with mortgages at 14% or 15%.  Despite that, houses had risen to sell for typically $200,000 to $300,000.  That is not a doubling in a decade - it is a 20 fold to 30 fold increase in 25 years!   So much for high interest rates killing any appreciation.  All  before foreign buyers.  Of course houses have gone up  roughly another 5 fold to 10 fold since then as rates came back down these past 35 years.  Moral of the story is that real estate  appreciated  more in a rising wage/rising mortgage rate environment  than it did in a tepid wage increase/mortgage rates decreasing one.

Comment: There are two issues involved here (aside from aboriginal claims) that should be kept separated in order to have a sensible discussion.

First, Premier Notley is correct in her assessment of jurisdictional issues.  The pipeline is an inter-provincial undertaking over which exclusive jurisdiction is granted to the federal government in the Constitution.  Any attempt to thwart that jurisdiction with such means as withholding or delaying licensing and permitting, would be rejected by the courts, perhaps with a substantial award of damages.

Premier Notley is also correct that the Pacific coast of Canada and seabed are not the property of British Columbia - they belong to the Crown in Right of Canada.

That said, IMO it is irrational to be contemplating pumping more diluted bitumen to the already congested Vancouver harbour or to a northern outlet where tankers would face the sometimes treacherous waterways such as Hecate Strait.

Comment: The ACA is loved by partisans, but it is tremendously flawed in that it does nothing to control the runaway costs of health care  Unfortunately, the Republicans are playing some dumb game with their bills which also entirely omit cost controls.  The free market does not work for services that are not discretionary and when supply is controlled to limit competition.  To solve the health care problem in the country we need universal medicare with strict limits on compensation rates.  Medical education should be subsidized and expanded introducing competition and eliminating the massive debt incurred in medical education. 
 The single-payer medicare system would eliminate all private insurance (reducing cost by about 20 percent overnight) and the rate setting feature would bring medical coverage down to levels where everyone gets the treatment needed without sapping the vitality of the country paying the massive costs that now prevail.

Comment: Personally, I led off the discussion with a speech about the importance of a trust-based approach in community organizations, but that this approach doesn't keep us from creating a smart process.  The RNA just created a vision statement, which we considered while making our decision:

"The RNA inclusively listens to Richmond residents and supports with integrity their collaborative engagement to improve the livability, accessibility, and safety of the neighborhood for all."

The board and membership had a good conversation about a trust-based versus a proof-based approach.  Even the minority opinion folks didn't seem to be trying to exclude eligible voters.  I think that ultimately, people want to believe in the system used to elect their neighborhood association board.

Cyd Manro,
RNA board chair

If the signal was made after crossing the bridge, it's about 2-300 ft, which is pretty tight in terms of it being 65 mph through there. RV guy should've seen that coming, or it didn't register. I've had a couple instances where southbound travelers have jumped into my northbound lane there to avoid hitting the bus turning right for the hotel. No left turn bay for northbound, nor deceleration lane for southbound; the turn is made straight off the lanes.

Comment: Penny was not just a businesswoman.  She was an advocate for appreciating what went into the vintage pieces that decorated her big store on Willamette Street.  You could get lost in there for hours, as I did on many Saturdays.  I loved the way the displays suggested over-stuffed rooms in a grand old house.  Dark wood, shelves lined with books, lamps and mirrors placed just so.  And if I had a question about a piece, she usually had the answer I was looking for.  She was generous with her time and often offered me insights into the things I wanted to buy.  She was kind and patient.  So I was heart-broken, but only for her, when she said the building's owners were forcing her to move.  It pleases me to hear they haven't found a buyer for the old building.  They deserve every setback coming their way for kicking Penny to the curb.  The antiques business is undergoing a sea-change.  It might be generational, it might be economic.  But Penny was there in the good times, doling out memories.

Comment: Mauicitizen

Is your shower head permanently affixed to your body and somehow constantly shooting water all over you which is "absorbed by [your] skin"?   I mean, most people learned how to avoid water coming out of a shower head, shortly after infancy.  If you don't like the content of the water coming out of your shower head, then take your showers elsewhere.  You are entirely free to do so.  There is no "force" involved.

Comment: I work in research. My particular focus is in Criminological studies relating to prison systems, primarily those in Ontario. However, I have hands on work experience with Indigenous young people, on and off the reserves in southern and central Ontario; I also worked closely with child welfare as the majority of my clients were from this system.
While I recognize that money does not repair everything, I do believe that in those extreme cases of $2000 or $3000 per student funding differences (not the case for all First Nations), this is essentially the difference between having proper supplies, proper staffing, experienced/skilled educators, a proper library, sports/recreation, or even having appropriate fiscal support to include on the land learning opportunities (another fun read to look for some papers on, this is a new education trend).
Don Drummond has done a fair bit of work actually measuring this funding gap. Worth a read in general he presents some interesting results.

Comment: In the marine safety world, what a vessel should have aboard, especially for a voyage like this, is an EPIRB - Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon - that sends one's coordinates to SAR resources upon being manually or automatically (hydrostatic release) activated, and is registered to the ship so they know exactly what they're looking for and where.

Satellite phone is a nice extra, as is a SPOT device that even most non-mariners are aware of.

That they missed acquiring such basic survival gear makes you wonder what kind of "veteran sailors" they consulted before casting off.

The headline for this story should read "Idiots lucky to be alive; lost at sea 5 months for no good reason"

Comment: I recommend reading, Beyond the Ivory Tower,
Social Responsibilities of the Modern University, by Derek Bok
I read this about the time my son entered the 2nd grade (eighties); it gives good insight into the negative effects of federal funding on our educational system. Thus the rapid rise and growth of the administrative educational complex.
We were blessed with great teachers, but the pace and progress in the classroom was dismal at best because a third or better of the class couldn't read, and still others had difficulty with comprehension. I was a parent volunteer and stunned to learn that the entire 2nd grade class passed to the next grade level. 
Increasing education funding and preschool will not change the results of this type of study. Education funding in Anchorage has increased three fold since my son was in school and the results are pretty much the same; except administration has grown out of proportion and costs have skyrocketed with no accountability/improvement.

Comment: However they acquired the land is not the issue. The issue is that they use a market driven mechanism (dynamic) to establish the economic rent, e.g. stumpage and that we used an administrative process (fixed) to establish the rent. If our stumpage fees are lower than the market (as opposed to rising to the market), the U.S. perceives that our companies are receiving a subsidy.

As long as we have two totally different systems we will continue to see trade disputes and challenges. Why not try and find a way to totally avoid these disputes in the future and let industry on both sides of the border adapt to the rules?

Comment: AJ, you are conflating the work of Arthur Laffer with supply side Economics, and misrepresenting one of his main tenets.

Laffer did not advocate lowering taxes as a way to stimulate economic growth as a central principle.
He proved empirically and scientificially that there is a level (percentage or proportion) of tax rates beyond which the actual taxes collected will be lower than if the tax rate had been kept at the lower level.
In other words, continually raising taxes can be self-defeating.

Under the socialist labour government in Britain in the 1960's the top marginal tax rate was 83%, plus a 15% "Super tax" = 98% on unearned income.

98 per frikkin cent!

How many people do you think actually paid that kind of tax, and how much super tax was collected?

Comment: As I recall, this whole thing about bumping rights developed in the 1980s was designed to help the consumer receive some compensation for accidental overbooking. Shame on the airlines industry for overstepping their bounds. Comment: My son's a high functioning autistic.  Beautiful, intelligent, thoughtful kid.  He can play in the water for hours.  Tunes out and loses himself in it, which isn't a problem in a pool, as he's a good swimmer, but is a real problem in a less controlled setting.  We found out the implications of that the hard way when he strayed - just 15 feet or so - off Santa Monica beach and got caught in a rip current.  That was my fault.  My nephew and I tried to bring him back, but we all got caught and nearly drowned.  We were dragged out at the last moment by a couple of lifeguards who very literally saved our lives.  

My son has had swimming lessons for much of his life.  They were money well spent, because they probably kept him alive until help arrived.  I'm not sure they should be publicly funded - we've already benefitted from tens of thousands of dollars in public funding which have helped him enormously - but I'd spend my own money on that before lots of other things, I can tell you.

Comment: Wrong, Kiragirl.  Revenue passengers can still get bumped to make room for crew members flying standby if crew members make known their “must fly” situation at least 60 minutes before scheduled flight departure.  These are crew members who opt to live far from their home airports and fly standby to get to and from work.   This practice is fine as long as seats are available for standby passengers.  Bumping occurs when flights are fully booked or when they don’t have enough seats for all crew members flying standby who must get to their assigned airports to avoid cancellations of the flights they are scheduled to fly.  Revenue passenger, in effect, get bumped for crew members who could and should reside within ground commuting distance of their assigned airports but for personal reasons or convenience opt to reside far away and commute to work by air.  It is a self-inflicted airline problem which does not benefit passengers who get bumped.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: Officials: 17-year-old Muslim girl assaulted and killed after leaving Virginia mosque
Police found remains Sunday thought to be those of a missing Virginia teenager who they say was assaulted and disappeared overnight after leaving a mosque in the Sterling area, and a 22-year-old man has been charged with murder in connection with the case.
The mosque, the All Dulles Area Muslim Society (ADAMS) in Sterling, and relatives identified the girl as 17-year-old Nabra Hassanen of Reston.
Fairfax County police identified the man charged with murder in her death as Darwin Martinez Torres of Sterling.
According to accounts from police and a mosque official, a group of four or five teens were walking back from breakfast at IHOP early Sunday when they were confronted by a motorist. All but one of the teens ran to the mosque, where the group reported that the girl had been left behind, according to Deputy Aleksandra Kowalski, a spokeswoman for the Loudoun County Sheriff’s Office.

Comment: Who was the "poll" conducted by?  Oh, I guess that doesn't matter. Comment: I have a problem with false assumptions, not deductions. 

Pass a test to exercise a constitutional right? I don't think that will pass muster. Would you also require a test, say, for literacy, to vote? 

How would you force gun owners to register their existing weapons? Search and seizure? That won't fly either, but for EVERY new purchase? Absolutely. 

How about extending liability laws in some manner: If a gun is used in a murder and the seller broke some law in getting the killer the weapon, the seller can also be charged as an accessory? 

How about a massive, voluntary buy back program that pays three or four times a weapon's worth? Won't eliminate guns, but would drive costs sky high so that even the black market guns would be out of reach of low-level bad guys and most suicidal folks. This could even be done with private funds. 

How about a new organization to compete with the NRA? One for "good" gun owners that actually focuses on training and safety?

Comment: There is a problem with thinking that gains in the current account will balance deficits in the trade account. While the numbers may balance your trading partner who enjoys a large trade surplus and therefore ends up with a large surplus of your currency now uses your own money to buy large positions in your leading companies or government bonds which now pay dividends or interest and we send even more money. In many cases they end up acquiring many valuable assets as we have seen happening here in Canada. Ultimately your trading partner runs out of reasons to buy more of your assets.
The goal of global trading is to have a balanced  trading positon with your various trading partners. Thinking that the current account can balance a trade deficit is not sustainable

Comment: I have been married over 40 years. I can't claim to have a definative answer. But I think the process includes the following steps are:
1) Listening for problems
2) Caring/owning the problem
3) Helping to solve the problem
4) Admitting you are wrong when you are wrong.
5) Cooperating with any solution that is mutually acceptable.
6) Show some progress in solving the problem.
7) Give your partner praise for progress.
8) Instill an attitude with humour, cooperation, and state of happiness.
9) When solved celebrate jointly.
10) Go back to #1.
(It took me a long time to figure this out)

Comment: This is the first chance for immigration minister Hussen to put his stamp on the department and policy and he has done a decent job in that regard.

The economic need for more immigrants especially in some regions and some occupations was well stated by the minister as was the efficacy in terms of predictability and planning of a longer 3 year as opposed to one year approach to setting quotas.

I would like to see 75% rather than 60% of the immigrant quota come from the economic class but suspect this was the best the minister got out of his pandering lefty cabinet.

The annual immigration quota target 1% of population was what PM Mulroney had in mind when he dramatically increased immigration from the roughly 100,000 a year during Trudeau 1.0's era to over 250,000 a year by 1992.   Mulroney also increased the % of the total quota in the economic class.

In this as in trade, taxation, regulation and most related matters, Mulroney set the economic agenda for Canada for 2 generations.

Comment: The historian Peter Gay, writing about the end of the Enlightenment (in his amazing two-volume work), said that Europe "lost its nerve." People lost confidence that they could work rationally to solve problems, that they could mine the creativity of the populace, that they could work in some combination of togetherness and individuality to overcome the sad and tragic patterns of history that seemed to enslave countries and dictate events, the oppression of king and Church, the wasting of human talent and potential, the squandering of initiative and enthusiasm, and achieve victory over ignorance and lack of broad education. I see this verdict applying to the U.S. and to much of the world now, Western democratic countries in particular. There is a loss of nerve. It's as if everyone has given up, across broad bands of society. There is no trust in clear thinking and respectful pooling of ideas.

Comment: You do have a constitutional right to bail, (8th amendment) except there are conditions to which it can be denied. For example, if the suspect poses a clear and imminent risk to the general public.Also, in situations where it is likely the accused will attempt to allude the legal process. In these situations, it has been accepted that "no bail" is not considered excessive bail.
.
imo bail should not be provided for an individual accused of new crimes that occurred while out on bail. I also think that denial of bail should be an additional consideration by grand jury during the indictment process for violent crimes. I think that their potential risk to society can be argued by looking at the heinousness of the crime and relationship to the victim(s) (likeliness to be a danger to the general public) as well as whether or not they clearly attempted to allude police when arrested. (likeliness they will appear in court).

Comment: Taking another tack on this discussion, I have some familiarity with some of the principals that are featured in this article. I will say that their support does not lie in judging the candidate as a person. It more lies, instead, on undying support for the Republican Party. 

Unyielding support for the party is one thing, and bless anyone's heart for having that much principal toward a organizational cause like a political party. But for them who do have this much support, I ask "where do you draw the line between the character of a person and the philosophy of a party?" 

Because at the end, a political party, or any organizaiton for that matter, is made up of people. And the character of the people who represent it are going to be the ones that "the rest of us" are going to look at in judging whom we want to be represented by.

Comment: Trump's plan would more than double the standard deduction to $15,000. But that change would be outweighed by his elimination of personal exemptions and head-of-household status. So the family's taxable income would be $60,000, and their tax bill would be $2,440 more than it is now.
Trump's advisers deny that he will raise taxes on middle-income Americans. Stephen Miller, his top policy adviser, said Trump would provide tax-free child care savings accounts and other provisions to enable some families to reduce taxes.
But Batchelder's analysis found that those provisions wouldn't be enough to offset the plan's other elements that would increase taxes for some middle income households.
All independent analyses show most of the benefit of Trump's plan flowing to the wealthiest Americans. Nearly half of Trump's tax cuts would go to the top 1 percent of earners, the Tax Policy Center found. Less than a quarter of the cuts would benefit the bottom 80 percent.

Comment: I tend to disagree.  I hate going to doctor's offices because they're run down and I've never received good customer service from a GP's receptionist.  I compare that to my experience in hospitals and urgent care centres where the doctors focus on being doctors and the running of the business is left to professional administrators.  I would choose an urgent care centre over a walk-in clinic every time.  We should just get rid of the private doctor's offices and have the hospital organizations open and run non-urgent GP facilities.  The hospitals already have the skills in place to effectively administer these facilities.  That would allow us to move away from the bill for service model and go to an employee/employer model.  It would also provide some transparency into the very mirky waters of doctor compensation.

As an aside, most highly paid professionals work a lot more than a 40 hour week. It's the bargain you make with your employer in return for the higher pay.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Comment: There are two ways to put a number on crimes. You can ask how many get tracked by police from reports to them by victims. Or you can have people self-report in a poll, no police involved.

With the first method, the number of police-reported sexual assaults has declined by about 20% in past years, in keeping with drops of some other crimes by over 20%. So the picture is crimes are dropping in frequency, and a variety of crimes fit this trend, including sexual assaults. And this would not be surprising, as Canada is an aging population, with fewer males in their teens, 20s and 30s, when most violent crimes are performed (males are more often perpetrators of violent crimes).

But with the second method, self-reporting in a poll, the exact same rates of self-reported sexual assault have stayed constant and not budged at all.

Given that MASSIVE gulf in alignment, it is strange that the reporter selects only quotes from people convinced that the second method perfectly reflects truth.

The firearms dealer doesn't actually 'see' the NCIC report of a purchaser, they only receive a confirmation or denial of purchase  so there's not really anything to judge from their end... In regards to liability, the government is immune from any save for proximate causation which isn't really an argument here. You may be thinking of the Dylan Roof case - where his pending charges in state court should have shown up on his attempt to purchase the firearm that he used, but that one also slipped through the cracks. As a responsible multiple-gun owner myself, it's very sad and very frustrating to see the government fail in its own obligation to not allow prohibited people purchase firearms. The laws here, like in Vegas, were already in place.

Comment: You are probably the silliest poster who ever dribbled on a keyboard.  Oh well, it's a quiet evening, might as well have some fun.  

Most of BC's earliest coastal cutblocks regenerated naturally, with no help from us at all.  These originated  in the very late 1800's to early 1900's and are now in the  > 100 yr age class. These stands are now approaching mid seral stages of succession, past their culmination of mean annual increment and so robust as to appear nearly 'old growth' in character.  The capacity for recovery and biomass accumulation in these  biogeoclimatic subzones is somewhat better than we originally thought when drafting early growth and yield models. 

The mechanism of regeneration is another area in which you are darkly ignorant. Coastal forest regeneration almost always is a composite of planted and advanced natural growth, which is why foresters do regeneration surveys ahead of reforestation.  

I'll clear up further misunderstandings once you've settled down.

Comment: For perspective: In 2006, the population of Texas was 23,507,783, of which, according to the Strayhorn study, 1,400,000 (5.96%) were aliens. Absent aliens, the population would be 22,107,783, and GSP would be 17.7 billion less, or $1.032 trillion. Per capita GSP would be $46,694.
Hmmmm ... a per capita gain of $2,000+ absent aliens. 
(Actually, at least $2,000 - the presence of aliens probably depressed wages overall.)

Comment: Did you notice that GDP growth is highest in Canada among the G-7 countries? How did we do that when oil prices have crashed in the last 2 years? I suggest that Canada's immigration policy may be the root cause of our relative outperformance. Taking in 0.6% of the net population almost every year since 1988 has left Canada (overall) demographically robust - with the exception of the demographically challenged Atlantic provinces.

Despite a President committed to "growth policies", the USA trail badly. Perhaps, that's because of its anti-immigrant bias which, in aggregate, discourages national consumer spending.

Canada's twin emphasis on selecting the best independent immigrants plus accepting refugees has proven to be worthwhile. 

Still, it is true that even a modestly expanding national population can lead to housing shortages in areas where population growth is robust. Reining in the distorting effects of foreign "hot money" is one action that can offer some modestlylimited relief.

Comment: While I agree in principle - moving police authority to the local level is not a silver bullet - there are downsides, and they must be planned for and mitigated if this is to achieve good outcomes. The biggest downside is that corruption, abuse of power, police brutality and similar problems are likely to go up. 
Without the large structure of a national policing authority including the IPID police under local authority tend to be able to get away with things that are otherwise easier to stop. In the USA for example the most corruption police forces have consistently been small town sherrifs. This is also where the worst abuses of power happens. To give an example, a recent case in the USA, had a small town along a major Texas highway where police habitually pulled over and arrested any car with out-of-state plates and a black driver with no grounds. Then pressured the drivers to pay exorbitant fines for trumped up charges. Those fines were 30% of the Town's revenue !

Comment: "It may be that the US is ceasing to be a great and enlightened country..."

So the myth goes.  "Great"?  In industrial terms, up to about 50 years ago, no question. Those times are gone, for a variety of reasons, and will not return for generations--if at all.  In military terms?  No question.  Until, again, about 50 years ago, when America's US Marines-led conquest of foreign lands ("From the halls of Montezuma to the shores of Tripoli...") started to fault and fail. 

Enlightened?  Rarely.  Not that Americans were stupid.  They--like Canadians--remained blissfully unaware, for the most part.  Uninformed rather than ill-informed.  The advent of electronic media (radio/TV/the web) was to change all that.  It hasn't.  Now Americans are--like many Canadians--both uninformed AND ill-informed.  

 "...you may be more concerned about making America wise again."  History tells us that many times, neither Canada nor America was 'wise' at all.

Comment: Ken Rocheleau - When my mother and father graduated from high school -- in different states and in 1941 and 1931 respectively -- they both had to stand for boards on several subjects, high school then being much more like college now. One was on US history and another was on the Constitution. They grew up to have fairly different views of politics, but both could still quote verbatim the Constitution and Amendments as they had been at the time of their graduation. Dad admired some of Europe's progressive policies, but he would always say "Of course, we can't do that here because the Constitution doesn't give our government that sort of power" and Mom would say "Thank the Founders for their foresight."

That right there would go a long way to teaching students how to be good citizens. I would much prefer that over teachers indoctrinating them in whatever the latest propaganda is about "citizenship."

Simply put, do you want autonomy over your personal affairs, or do you want the state to intrude into virtually all of them by limiting your ability to give consent?

Clearly, some advocates are for limiting your right to consent. Their goal is to specifically protect people who voluntarily render themselves in a vulnerable state. In doing so they would limit the right of everyone to consent regardless of the circumstances.

Taking away everyone's personal autonomy is a poor solution to dealing with those who are reckless with it.

Comment: Dear Ms. Schwartz,

The initiative process is not illegal.  It is a process established by law.  We followed the law and got over 15% of the voters in the last Gubernatorial election to sign the petition for initiative.  We got 22% to be exact, thanks to 200 gatherers, which hardly qualifies as a sneaky operation.  The ordinance governing initiatives allows the county council to adopt the ones that obviously have overwhelming popular support.  This is because we live in a representative democracy and most laws are written and enacted by our elected officials.  It is, in fact, unusual for a new law to be put directly to the people for a vote and should only be done in cases where the elected officials feel they for some reason cannot support making the law themselves.  If you don't like the system of laws and representation, work to change it instead of accusing people of sneaky railroading because they effectively, legally and loudly advocated for a law you don't like.

Comment: A single-payer system would be a boon for our businesses, other than the insurance industry.  Imagine businesses not being fettered with providing health insurance as a mandatory practice.  Even before Obamacare, large businesses would quickly lose good workers if they failed to provide insurance.  This practice created a disincentive for people to start small businesses because they would have to enter a non-pooled insurance group and pay much more.  It also makes it more difficult for employees to switch jobs or leave the workforce to take care of their children.  Last, the businesses essentially paid for catastrophic care for everyone.  People without insurance did not pay their medical bills when a major accident or illness occurred, but hospitals still had to receive those patients. Note that BC rolled back an additional 4% increase to premiums for 2016 due to this being an election year.  No doubt that will be nicely tacked on come 2018 if the BC Liberals are re-elected.

Comment: Quebec's reputation as king maker stemmed from the tradition of a "Quebec solide"-where Quebec would overwhelmingly move to either the Conservatives or the Liberals. In the two-party era, that was often decisive. With more parties in the mix in Quebec (and elsewhere), coupled with its declining share of the total seats, Quebec's impact is attenuated, and greatly influenced by seat distributions elsewhere. At the same time, the perception that a party and its leader are competitive in Quebec , may well influence the propensity of voters in other provinces to take them seriously as an alternative government. I think O'Leary's rationale was entirely credible.

Comment: Hot new major? Programs in game development have been around for at least 16 years. Various private colleges in the USA have offered them for ages. Speaking as someone who recruits college graduates for one of the world's top companies, I would do a more flexible major and read up on game development on the side (or pursue the concentration option that you mention). The reason being that all industries are cyclical, and if you specialize just in game development it will be hard to convince someone in another field that you have the right skills when the market turns. I had a friend at Radical Entertainment who kicked himself for getting a specialized gaming degree as opposed to a proper BSc or BEng.

Comment: In 2001, following free speech challenges from both the left and the right to professors at the University of Alaska, then-university president Mark Hamilton sent out a brief, absolutely unambiguous memo regarding the university's commitment to ALL free speech. He showed how every university administrator should address these challenges.

From his memo:

"What I want to make clear and unambiguous is that responses to complaints or demands for action regarding constitutionally guaranteed freedoms of speech CANNOT BE QUALIFIED...Opinions expressed by our employees, students, faculty or administrators don't have to be politic or polite. However personally offended we might be, however unfair the association of the University to the opinion might be, I insist that we remain a certain trumpet on this most precious of Constitutional rights."

https://www.cs.uaf.edu/~chappell/misc/freesp.html

Comment: With no changes in the budget, the annual federal debt will increase again after seven years of shrinking under Obama. The reason is that the "baby boom" generation is getting old and going on Social Security and Medicare, which are two large parts of the federal budget. What is needed is an increase in revenues, especially in withholding taxes which pay for SS, Medicare and Medicaid. This could be done relatively painlessly by raising the cap on contributions. Additionally, increasing the top tax bracket while raising each bracket limit to account for inflation would be fair and simple. In addition long-term carried interest, which is income, should be taxed at the same rate, and with the same brackets, as income taxes.

However, Republicans want to eliminate many taxes and lower all taxes upon the wealthy, while increasing military spending. This would blow up the deficits tremendously. Is this a surprise? It shouldn't be, because every Republican president since Ford has lowered...

Comment: Lagging pay and less work is an indicator of a labour shortage which corporations use to try and gain a competitive advantage or at least to maintain a level playing field with their peer companies. 

It also means that taxpayers are increasingly underwriting the labour costs of corporations as many of their employees have to supplement their incomes with social supports to survive.

This is a further indication that strong corporate earnings in a globalized economy are not shared and tend to accrue at the top thus increasing the wealth gap.

It is time that the provincial governments increased the minimum wage and taxed away the cost of social supports.  This would only be mildly inflationary, would increase the amount of money in circulation, and over the long term be beneficial to both business and society.

Comment: Dave neglects to mention that CPI-common, the measure clocking at a ludicrously low 1.3% for January, is a slightly different measure from the common component of CPI measure that Poloz and other Bank of Canada bigwigs were lauding prior to the dysfunctional 2016 renewal of the inflation-control agreement. Where the former was based on the CPI All-items and included changes in indirect taxes, the second is based on the CPIXT and more or less excludes changes in indirect taxes. Comment: Your claim is false, alwordman. The government of Canada does not distinguish between religions for the purposes of tax exemptions. (In fact, it's prevented from doing so by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.) Whether a group is a "cult" or a major religion, it will receive charitable tax exemptions on the basis of criteria laid down by CRA. The criteria are: 

1.   Maintaining the basic requirements of charitable 
status
2.   Devoting resources to charitable activities
3.   Avoiding private foundation designation 
4.   Ensuring that a public benefit is achieved
5.   Restricting political activities
6.   Filing information returns with CRA
7.   Meeting the disbursement quota requirement
8.   Keeping adequate records and books

As you can see, there's nothing there that distinguishes between religions, cults or any other form of belief or non-belief.

Comment: There is absolutely no need to reserve a camping spot or a hotel room, even though people are doing it in great numbers.  The whole eclipse will last only about 2 minutes.  So, just drive to any spot within the 70- mile band across Oregon, stop at a place where the sky and the sun are clearly visible around 10 am, and wait for the total eclipse to happen.  Then you can go home.  Only the total eclipse is interesting. That's when you can look directly at the sun. The dark disk you will see there will actually be the moon.  For about an hour before and an hour after the eclipse, you will notice some darkening  but nothing spectacular.  If you are anywhere outside of the totality (such as in Portland or Eugene), you will not see anything worth writing about.   Only the totality is interesting.  And the closer you are to the center line of the band of totality, the longer you will be able to observe the total eclipse (up to a maximum of about 2 minutes).

Comment: I'm going to assume that the honor will go to the PLAINS bison.  The WOOD bison that are at the wildlife conservation center in Portage and recently transferred to the lower Yukon River valley are not quite the same animal.  Wood bison are a northern bison.  The animals described in the article are the southern bison.  

This can confuse folks traveling up the Alaska Highway in the Yukon and then up near Delta Junction, to think these are the same bison, when they are not.  Folks thought the wood bison were extinct, so plains bison were brought up to Alaska in the 1930's.  It might be an interesting story for ADN to follow up on both the wood and plains bison found in Alaska, since it may be that many folks don't know there's a difference.

Comment: I personally felt that the BoC had adequately signaled its intent to raise rates, and was not surprised at all to find they had. Normally I would think the criticism ill-founded, except that it comes from no less than Douglas Porter himself. Out of great respect for him, I will defer of course to his judgment.

But I can see how the signals could be considered unclear, and how the forecasting may have been excessively challenging. Changes in the overnight rate are predicated on inflation, and the core rate is remaining stubbornly low, under 2%. I'm certainly not complaining about low and consistent inflation, but I can understand the confusion when everything but the inflation rate seems to have determined the interest rate hike. 

After so many years of static rates and tired pedantic pronouncements, my heart flutters at this macroeconomic melodrama.

Comment: Gas tax and auto registration fees go to pay for federal and state highways, not local roads where most people ride bicycles. Local roads are paid for via bonds, income taxes, property taxes, and sales taxes. Most, if not all, bicyclists pay these taxes, and therefore pay for the roads they use.

Comment: The first thing that has to change re: diet is to replace "false nutrients" with real food.   The problem took decades to develop fully, and it will take about as long to unwind, I would wager.   The brain is programmed to seek an adequate level of nutrition.   If it doesn't obtain the nutrition, the brain (the subconscious) will tell people to keep eating.   Good, nutritious food satisfies the brain;  poor substitutes don't.

There are some signs of hope in Canada.  Among the "Millennial" generation, there seems to be a much higher general level of awareness than, say, among the Boomers.    The places that sell the healthiest food in my neighbourhood are all run by people who are in that cohort and they are enthusiastic.

There are good signs when there is acknowledgement in the US that large-scale agri-operations are destroying the soil and reducing the nutrition in food.   There are moves for more agriculture to happen on a blended organic/conventional model in the US.

Comment: We had exactly those conditions a few years ago.
A double wave from the Sun. The first was slower and we saw coming over the course of 1-2 days.

It missed the Earth, on the plane of the Earth's orbit. Had the event happened two weeks later, on the same trajectory it would have been a direct hit with minimal warning.

Comment: "I'm a Keynesian and I support the financial strategy of the Federal Liberals. "

Those statements are incompatible.

A Keynesian would know that one of Keynes's fundamental points was that deficit spending during the expansionary phase of the cycle merely buys forwards growth from a later phase, at a premium - you get ½% growth now but give up 1% in the future. Eventually you have to throw more and more stimulus to achieve the same growth.

Keynes also showed that the stimulatory effects decline to zero as Government spending approaches 20% of GDP. We are well above that now.

Since the increase in deficit has gone primarily to program spending, not Infrastructure spending, Keynes would be spinning in his grave.

Comment: The estate tax does NOT affect everyone who inherits property from their parents. Please read some accurate information about the "death tax" and don't listen to Trump.

For couples, the first $11 million in their estate is not taxable; only the amount that exceeds $11 million is taxable. Anyone with an estate that is subject to the estate tax has accountants and estate planners who can help them shield far more than $11 million. Crummey trusts and life insurance trusts are among the ways that allow you to pass money to your children in addition to the $11 million that is tax-exempt. I set up trusts many years ago to protect the portion of my estate that exceeds the amount of the estate tax exemption, so I speak from experience.

Comment: (CONTINUED FROM ABOVE):

(4) And perhaps most importantly in the context of this discussion, F. catus kills on reflex at the sight of movement regardless of hunger--it's killing and feeding reflexes are controlled by separate regions of its little brain.  We bred them that way.  Wild cats don't do that.  They kill for hunger, to feed their young and to teach them to hunt.

(5) Fluffy doesn't control rodents, she ATTRACTS 'em.  She and her little mousey playmates trade T. gondii oocysts back and forth like poker chips.  When she kills and eats a bit of them, the parasites return to her digestive tract to reproduce and the cycle is complete.  And T. gondii eats your brain.  Among other things.

(6) Evidence for the above is that Australia has been overrun with feral cats for better than a century and overrun with MICE just as long.  In fact by destroying native rodents cats facilitate the spread of invasive pest rodent species.  80-90% of Australian feral cats are infected with toxo.

Comment: Too many Canadians criticize our Federal Government & its agencies for (a) not aggressively & publically rebutting outlandish tweets & comments made by US officials regarding Canada-US trade, & (b) not publically presenting Canada's own list of demands for change in Canada-US-Mexico trade relations.

I'm not a Liberal Party supporter but I have no doubt that our Government's senior political & public service officials work diligently on the US/Canada trade file which is central to Canada's well-being. Any Canadian Government would be diligent in current circumstances & Canadians longstanding experience managing this file.

The key is to carefully prioritize our case & present it resolutely but not gratuitously offensively at the right time and place.  Mouthing off publicly now makes good street theatre but poor tactics.

Canadians should stay calm, reassure our leaders that we're prepared to accept sacrifice rather than cave-in & not be distracted by current US street theatre.

Comment: Sorry, Brother, but I am afraid we disagree fundamentally about the evidence on the female diaconate. 

First, unambiguously, up until the 8th century, women were ordained deacons in the Byzantine Church. We have copies of the ordination rituals used, and there are in the East three unambiguous markers of major orders: (1) laying on of hands, (2) epiklesis, and (3) the ordination takes place within sanctuary (behind the iconostasis). All three conditions are well documented for men and women deacons; as well of course as male priests and male bishops. 

Second, Macy has recently reported that there is evidence of female deacons in the West in the 12th century, somewhere in northern Europe. I do not have the citation for this, as I only heard him report this orally about six months ago at a conference on the female diaconate in Toronto, and I don't recall whether it had been published by then. 
(continued)

Comment: Even 30 months is too long (excluding delays caused by the defence and force majeure).  That's two and a half years to have a criminal charge hanging over your head!

Yes, a shortage of judicial resources is part of the problem but I would argue that's actually only a symptom.  The real problem is judges who are too timid to take authoritative control of the proceedings in their court rooms and allow matters to be dragged out, thereby soaking up what resources are available.  There are numerous manifestations of this.  Some examples:

- a court date is set for the purpose of fixing yet another court date (e.g. for a sentencing hearing).
- defence counsel are allowed to go on open-ended fishing expeditions without laying any reasonable foundation for same.
- police making last minute disclosures of evidence (don't grant an adjournment - that only encourages them - just exclude it unless it is exculpatory).
- Crown Counsel being ill-prepared (cf. Ghomeshi).

Comment: The Springfield School Board is not alone in their assessment of the SBAC. Even the State of New York, which was originally a test state, decided to back out. While the idea of standardized testing has merit, it also has drawbacks. It means the materials used for teaching must be standardized, but in our highly politicized environment this also means people currently in power with whom you may disagree will be deciding what your child is taught. This material may include far more in the way of world views and opinions than objective facts. Even what is fact and what is not may be in dispute. Alternatively, local control of learning content makes it more difficult to compare results.

Here is another link of interest, (also see links from Roxana Marachi, PhD in the comments):

https://seattleducation2010.wordpress.com/2015/03/08/what-i-learned-taking-the-smarter-balanced-sbac-test/
